summary_reasoning: The report contains mostly restated company and sector narratives (moat via benchmarks, regulation favoring incumbents, competition in Market Intelligence) with limited new angles. There are at least two mild syntheses: linking long‑term fee increases (rack rates rising to 8.1 bps) to durable pricing power, and tying post‑IHS Markit diversification to a narrower revenue volatility range. Forecasts such as margins reaching ~52% by 2029 and ratings growth reverting to mid/high single digits are quantified and company‑specific, but the mechanisms (GDP growth, pricing, expense discipline) are standard. The mobility spinoff call includes a timeline and rationale but largely mirrors public disclosures. Decision relevance is moderate in several items (pricing cadence, margin trajectory, spinoff timing, ratings growth guide), yet the valuation section relies on boilerplate DCF inputs and generic drivers without a novel mechanism, triggering a hard cap at Fair. No original thesis with explicit causal links, unique drivers, or catalysts beyond management guidance was observed, and more than three insights are restated/generic.

insights_classified.text: IHS Markit’s recurring revenue model diversified S&P’s revenue, limiting upside and downside scenarios.
Adjusted operating margin to ~52% by 2029 (vs 49% in 2024), attributed to revenue growth and expense discipline.
Ratings rack rate increased to 8.1 bps in 2025 (6.25 in 2016; 4.25 in 2007), implying 3%–4% annual fee growth; pricing power remains strong.
Indexes’ exclusive derivatives agreements (e.g., CBOE) run to 2032; liquidity network effects sustain royalties.
Mobility division to be spun off in 2026; moaty but limited fit with other segments.
Regulation often benefits incumbents; S&P can pass increased compliance costs to issuers.
Ratings revenue ~1% in 2025, then mid/high single-digit growth driven by nominal GDP and pricing.

red_flags: Generic DCF with no novel drivers
